text:

Labour has at least one thing in common with the era of Tony Blair and Gordon Brown when it commissions a giant opinion poll to find out what the public thinks of the current leadership. 
Time was when Jeremy Corbyn and John McDonnell condemned New Labour ’s focus on group politics. But that was then and this is now. 
Discovering what voters feel through the semi-scientific analysis of opinion polls, as long as the results are read with a pinch of salt after recent failures, is entirely legitimate. 
What would be less defensible is a leader giving the go-ahead for a mega poll then keeping the findings secret – warts and all. 
If Corbyn is to mould a leadership team, he needs to start trusting colleagues like Deputy Leader Tom Watson and his Shadow Cabinet. 
Corbyn preached inclusion and openness when on the outer rim of Labour in Westminster. The leader should put his words into action by sharing details of his strengths and weaknesses. Like us on Facebook
